SHORT_DESCRIPTION: his dataset includes quadriceps and vastus lateralis ultrasound imaging from 88 older adults (mean age: 75.9 years, mean height: 162 cm, mean weight: 72.1 kg). For information on the group stratification of individual IDs within the dataset (non-sarcopenic, pre-sarcopenic, and sarcopenic), please contact Dr. Fabio Sarto at fabio.sarto@unipd.it. Group assignments will be provided upon request. A 47 mm, 7.5MHz linear array transducer was employed to collect all the ultrasound images. Femur length was measured as the distance between the greater trochanter and the mid-patellar point, with 0% representing the mid-patellar point (distal part) and 100% the greater trochanter (proximal part). Quadriceps femoris cross-sectional area (CSA) was assessed at three different muscle regions (30%, 50%, and 70% of femur length) using panoramic ultrasound imaging (MyLab70, Esaote, Genoa, Italy). To obtain the CSA images, the transducer was moved slowly in a transverse plane from the medial border of the vastus medialis to the lateral borders of the vastus lateralis, while maintaining consistent pressure on the skin. Two CSA scans were obtained at each site. Vastus lateralis muscle architecture was evaluated by B-mode longitudinal ultrasound scans at 50% at 35% of femur length. Three longitudinal scans were collected for each site.
